questions.text: Sodium channels are particularly blocked by
questions.solution:
• Tetrodotoxin (TTX), one of the most potent poisons known, specifically blocks the Na+ channel. The ovaries of certain species of puffer fish (a highly priced delicacy in Japan !!!) contain TTX
  • Saxitoxin is another blocker of Na+ channels that is produced by reddish dinoflagellates. Shellfish eat the dinoflagellates and concentrate saxitoxin in their tissues. A person who eats these shellfish may experience life-threatening paralysis within 30 minutes after the meal.
  • Tetraethylammonium (TEA+), another poison blocks K+ channels

questions.text: If plasma volume  is  4L and haematocrit is 60% the blood volume would be:
questions.solution:
Calculation:

Total blood volume = Plasma volume / 1 - Hematocrit

Total blood volume = 4L / 1-0.6 = 10L

questions.text: Gap junctions are seen in all except
questions.solution:
Multiunit smooth muscle is made up of individual units of muscle cells with no (or few) gap junctions. Multiunit smooth muscles are found in structures such as iris of the eye, in which fine, graded contractions occur.

Cardiac muscle and single unit smooth muscle have gap junctions that provide low-resistance bridges for the spread of excitation from one fibre to another permitting them to function as a syncytium.

Retina also has gap junctions that permit rapid propagation of electrical activity and exchange of chemical messengers between the retinal neurons.

questions.text: True about nerve fibre ‘C’ is
questions.solution:
Type C fibers are the small unmyelinated nerve fibers.

Other options :

  • C fibres are least susceptible to hypoxia
  • C fibres are post ganglionic sympathetic fibres
  • C fibres  carry pain and temperature sensations.

Types of nerve fibres:

Fiber type Function Fiber diameter (μm) Conduction velocity (m/s)
Aα Proprioception, somatic motor 12-20 70-120
Aβ Touch ,pressure 5-12 30-70
Aγ Motor to muscle spindles 3-6 15-30
Aδ Pain, temperature 2-5 12-30
B Preganglionic autonomic <3 3-15
C, Dorsal root Pain, temperature 0.4-1.2 0.5-2
C, Sympathetic Post ganglionic sympathetic 0.3-1.3 0.7-2.3

Susceptibility of nerve fiber to:

  • Pressure A>B>C
  • Hypoxia is B>A>C
  • Local anaesthetic B >A-γ > A-δ > A-β > A-α > C

questions.text: True about type II B muscle fibre

choices.text: Not useful for intense movements of short duration

questions.solution:
• The type IIB muscle fibres contain little myoglobin and therefore are pale in colour, so they are sometimes called white fibres.
  • Type IIB fibres have higher myosin ATPase activity→ fast twitches.
  • They are adapted to perform rapid, forceful movements.
  • Slow oxidative fibres (type I fibres) are important for maintaining posture.

Classification of fibre types in skeletal muscle fibres:

  Type I Type IIA Type IIB
Other names Slow, oxidative (SO) Fast, oxidative, glycolytic (FOG) Fast, glycolytic (FG)
Colour Red Red White
Myosin ATPase activity Slow Fast Fast
Ca2+ -pumping capacity of sarcoplasmic reticulum Moderate High High
Diameter Small Large Large
Glycolytic capacity Moderate High High
Oxidative capacity High Moderate Low
Associated motor unit type Slow (S) FastResistant to fatigue(FR) Fast fatiguable (FF)

questions.text: During skeletal muscle contraction

choices.text: Both H and I band shorten
Both A and I band shorten
Both A and H band shorten

questions.solution:
During muscle contraction the two Z lines come closer; length of A band remains constant while the length of H and I band decreases; M line becomes more prominent.

  • The sarcomere is the contractile unit of the skeletal muscle fibre.
  • It is composed of thick and thin filaments
    • Thick filament  : Myosin (A bands)
    • Thin filaments : Actin, tropomyosin and troponin ( I bands)
  • H bands : lighter area in the centre of A band where , when the muscle is relaxed, the thin filaments do not overlap the thick filaments.
  • Z line : provides attachment to actin filaments. The area between two adjacent Z lines is called the sarcomere.
  • M line :  centre of A band. Here there are slender cross-connections that hold the thick filaments in proper array.
  • During contraction, the Z lines come closer to each other reducing the length of the sarcomere. Sliding of thin filament over thick filament (cross bridge formation) reduces the length of I and H band. The A band remains constant and M line becomes prominent.

questions.text: In the clinical ward rounds, the professor tests the vibratory sensations of a patient by placing a 128Hz tuning fork on his great toe. He explains the receptors involved rapidly adapt to ongoing stimuli. Which receptor is he referring to?
questions.solution:
Rapidly adapting receptors that sense 128 Hz (fast vibration) are Pacinian corpuscles.

Pacinian corpuscles are cutaneous mechanoreceptors, which consist of unmyelinated dendritic endings of a sensory nerve fiber, encapsulated by concentric lamellae of connective tissue. It gives them an onion peel-like appearance. They respond to deep pressure and fast vibration of frequencies ranging between 60 - 300 Hz. Pacinian corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors, adapting in a few hundredths of a second.

The below image shows the histology of the Pacinian corpuscle.

Other options : 

Option A - Merkel's discs are expanded dendritic endings, which respond to sustained pressure and touch. They are slow-adapting receptors, allowing one to determine the continuous touch of objects against the skin.

Option B - Ruffini's end organs are enlarged dendritic endings with elongated capsules. These adapt very slowly and therefore, are important for signaling continuous states of deformation of the tissues, such as heavy prolonged touch and pressure signals. They are also found in joint capsules and help to signal the degree of joint rotation.

Option D - Meissner’s corpuscles are elongated encapsulated nerve endings of a large myelinated sensory nerve fiber. They are abundant in the nonhairy parts of the skin (lips, fingertips). Meissner's corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors, particularly sensitive to the movement of objects over the surface of the skin, as well as to low-frequency vibration (5-40 Hz).

Related Pearl: Cutaneous Mechanoreceptor Systems

Receptor

Merkel’s disc

Meissner corpuscle

Ruffini end organ

Pacinian corpuscle

Location

Tip of epidermis(Basal keratinocytes)

Dermal papillae

Dermis

Dermis

Sustained pressure and touch

Fast vibration and deep pressure 

Adaptation

Slow

Slow

5

Related Pearl: Classification of Senses based on Type of Receptors

Types of Receptors
MECHANORECEPTORS
  • Pacinian corpuscles,
  • Meissner's corpuscles
  • Merkel's discs
  • Golgi Tendon and Muscle spindles
THERMORECEPTORS

ELECTROMAGNETIC RECEPTORS

CHEMORECEPTORS
  • Olfactory and gustatory receptors
  • Receptors of aortic and carotid bodies
  • Receptors in hypothalamus for Blood Glucose

questions.text: First physiological response to high environmental temperature is:
questions.solution:
The temperature control system uses three important mechanisms to reduce body heat when the body temperature becomes too great:

  • Vasodilation of skin blood vessels. In almost all areas of the body, the skin blood vessels become intensely dilated. This is caused by inhibition of the sympathetic centers in the posterior hypothalamus that cause vasoconstriction. Full vasodilation can increase the rate of heat transfer to the skin as much as eightfold.
  • Sweating
  • Decrease in heat production. The mechanisms that cause excess heat production, such as shivering and chemical thermogenesis, are strongly inhibited.

questions.text: Bruxism occurs in which phase of sleep
questions.solution:
• Bruxism can occur in all stages of sleep but it is more common in NREM2.
  • Sleep bruxism is characterised by tooth grinding and jaw clenching occurs during NREM sleep and less frequently in REM.
  • Abnormal sensorimotor processing within CNS level underlies the genesis of sleep bruxism.

questions.text: Daily rhythm regulation is by:
questions.solution:
The rhythmic fluctuations in the functioning of living beings follows a circadian rhythm that is synchronized to the day-night cycle in the environment. This synchronisation depends on the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN).

SCN receive information about the light–dark cycle via a special neural pathway, the retinohypothalamic fibers.

Efferents from the SCN initiate neural and humoral signals that entrain a wide variety of well-known circadian rhythms including the sleep–wake cycle and the secretion of the pineal hormone melatonin. 

In the absence of such synchronization, the circadian rhythm becomes progressively more out of phase with light-dark cycle because they are longer or shorter than 24 hours.

questions.text: Initiation of visual impulse is associated with

choices.text: Condensation of opsin with Vitamin A
Photoisomerisation and hydrolysis of visual purple

questions.solution: Rhodopsin or visual purple, the photosensitive pigment, is composed of opsin (a protein belonging to the superfamily of G protein–coupled receptors) and retinal (an aldehyde of vitamin A). When light strikes the photoreceptors, retinal is chemically transformed in a process called photoisomerization, which begins the transduction process.

questions.text: Repolarization of the entire myocardium proceeds from
questions.solution:
In isolated cardiac muscle the direction of depolarization and repolarization are in the same direction from endocardium to epicardium.

However for entire myocardium, depolarization proceeds from endocardium to epicardium whereas repolarisation proceeds in opposite direction.

questions.text: HV interval on ECG is for conduction

choices.text: From AV node to bundle of His
From  bundle of His and bundle branches to ventricles

questions.solution:
The HV interval displays the conduction time from the His bundle which is located just below the AV node, to the first identifiable onset of ventricular activation.

His bundle electrogram (HBE):

  • The HBE shows 3 deflections as shown in the figure:
His bundle waves Description
A Denotes AV node activation
H Denotes His bundle activation
V Denotes ventricular depolarization

With HBE and standard ECG leads, 3 intervals can be timed accurately:

Interval Recording Corresponding event
PA interval Time from first appearance of atrial depolarization to the A wave in HBE Conduction time from SA node to AV node
AH interval From A wave to start of H spike AV nodal conduction time
HV interval Time from start of H spike to start of QRS deflection in ECG Conduction in Bundle of His and bundle branches

questions.text: The threshold of carotid sinus baroreceptor is:
questions.solution:
Carotid sinus baroreceptors have a threshold for excitation of 50 mm Hg.

Baroreceptors:

  • Are stretch receptors located in the heart and adventitia of the blood vessels
  • Types based on location
    • Carotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions)
    • Cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions)
  • Afferents
    • Carotid sinus – branch of Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN) – the carotid sinus nerve (sinus nerve of Hering)
    • Aortic arch receptor- branch of Vagus nerve (X CN) - aortic depressor nerve
  • Center for Reflex
    • Medulla  (Nucleus Tractus Solitarius)
  • Efferents
    • Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart and vasculature
  • Most sensitive to pulse pressure>> MAP
  • Threshold for excitation- 50mm Hg
  • Responses when one Carotid sinus nerve is isolated and perfused with other baroreceptors denervated
    • Perfusion pressure <30mm Hg- no response
    • 70-110mm Hg- linear relationship between perfusion pressure and the fall in systemic BP and HR
    • >150mm Hg- no further increase in response as the degree of inhibition of sympathetic nerve is maximal

questions.text: Discharge from the baroreceptors cause inhibition of:
questions.solution:
Baroreceptor Reflex

  • Increased BP→ stimulation of baroreceptors → stimulation of NTS → inhibition of RVLM → inhibition of sympathetic system
  • Stimulation of NTS also stimulates CVC → parasymapathetic stimulation
  • Net effect = sympathetic inhibition and parasympathetic stimulation → decreased HR and BP
  • NTS- Nucleus Tractus Solitarius
  • CVLM- Caudal Ventrolateral Medulla
  • RVLM (VMC) – Rostral Ventrolateral Medulla (Vasomotor Center)
  • CVC (CIC) – Cardiovagal center (Cardioinhibitory center)

questions.text: 16.	A 30-year old man has an end diastolic volume of 200ml and end systolic volume of 150 mL. What is his ejection fraction(%)?
questions.solution:
• Ejection fraction= stroke volume/EDV
  • EF = EDV - ESV / EDV
  • EF = 200 - 150 / 200 = 0.25 or 25%

questions.text: Which of the following vessels have least velocity of blood flow in the circulatory system
questions.solution:
The velocity of blood flow is inversely proportional to vascular cross-sectional area.

                                      v = F/A

  • v= velocity
  • F= blood flow through the vessel
  • A=vascular cross sectional area
  • Capillaries have the maximum cross sectional area (4500 cm2) and aorta has the least cross sectional area (4.5 cm2). Thus, under resting conditions, the velocity is least in capillaries and highest in aorta.

questions.text: For cerebral blood flow to be doubled Pco2  should be:
questions.solution:
A 70% increase  in Paco2 (80mmHg)  approximately doubles the cerebral blood flow.

Cerebral Blood Flow

  • Normal cerebral blood flow→ 50-65mL/100g of brain tissue/min
  • For entire brain CBF→750-900mL/min (15% of the resting cardiac output)
  • Factors that increase CBF
    • Cerebral metabolic rate
    • ↑Arterial Pco2
      • 70% increase  in Paco2 (80mmHg)  approximately doubles the CBF
    • ↑H+ ion concentration
    • Hypoxia
    • Substances released from astrocytes- NO, K+, adenosine etc

questions.text: Skin edema(Wheal) is due to
questions.solution:
Triple Response of Lewis

  • If the skin is stroked firmly by a blunt object triple response develops
  • The sequence : Red reaction→ flare → wheal
  • Red reaction is independent of innervation , and is due to histamine mediated relaxation of the precapillary sphincters
  • Flare reaction (Flush, Axon reflex) is due to Substance P mediated arteriolar dilatation (antidromic conduction of afferent impulses via collaterals of the sensory nerve fibre that lead to release of vasoactive mediators)
  • Wheal (skin edema) is due to histamine mediated increased capillary permeability
  • Triple response is present after total sympathectomy
  • Flare is absent in locally anesthetized skin

questions.text: In which type of shock does cardiac output increase?
questions.solution: High cardiac output in septic shock is caused by arteriolar dilation in the infected tissues and by high metabolic rate and vasodilation elsewhere in the body, resulting from bacterial toxin stimulation of cellular metabolism and from high body temperature.

questions.text: Physiologic dead space is that due to:

choices.text: Wasted ventilation due to Va/Q imbalance
Wasted ventilation due to Va/Q imbalance plus anatomical dead space
Total dead space minus anatomical dead space
Anatomical dead space minus wasted ventilation due to Va/Q imbalance

questions.solution: Physiologic dead space is the total volume of the lungs that does not participate in gas exchange. Physiologic dead space includes the anatomic dead space of the conducting airways plus a functional dead space in the alveoli.

questions.text: All are the features of exercise except :
questions.solution:
Exercise causes the OHDC o shift to the right and not left.

Respiratory responses to exercise

Parameter Response
O2 consumption ↑
CO2 production ↑
Ventilation rate ↑ (matches O2 consumption/CO2 production)
Arterial Po2 and Pco2 No change
Arterial pH No change in moderate exercise↓ in strenuous exercise (lactic acidosis)
Venous Pco2 ↑
Pulmonary blood flow (cardiac output) ↑
V/Q ratios More evenly distributed in lung

Cardiovascular responses to exercise

Parameter Response
Heart rate ↑
Stroke volume ↑
Pulse pressure ↑ (increased stroke volume)
Cardiac output ↑↑
Venous return ↑
Mean arterial pressure ↑
Total peripheral resistance ↓(vasodilation in skeletal muscle)
Arteriovenous O2 difference Increased O2 consumption

questions.text: The transpulmonary pressure is the pressure difference between
questions.solution: Trans-pulmonary pressure is intra-alveolar pressure  minus intrapleural pressure, and it is a measure of the elastic forces in the lungs that tend to collapse the lungs at each instant of respiration (the recoil pressure)

questions.text: Largest fraction of CO2 is present in the blood as:
questions.solution:
Almost all of the CO2 carried in blood is in a chemically modified form, HCO3−, which accounts for more than 70% of the total CO2.

CO2 transport in blood

  • Dissolved form - 7%
  • Carbamino compounds - 23%
    • CO2 reacts directly with amine radicals of the hemoglobin molecule to form the compound carbaminohemoglobin
    • CO2 also reacts with the plasma proteins in the tissue capillaries
  • Bicarbonates - 70%

questions.text: The sigmoid nature of OHDC is because of

choices.text: Binding of one molecule of O2 increases the affinity for next molecule of O2
Alpha chain has more affinity for O2 than beta chain
Beta chain has more affinity for O2 than alpha chain

questions.solution:
• O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve is sigmoid due to change in affinity of the heme groups for O2 as each successive O2 molecule binds.
  • Binding of the first molecule of O2 to a heme group increases the affinity for the second O2 molecule, binding of the second O2 molecule increases the affinity for the third O2 molecule, and so forth.
  • Affinity for the fourth, and last, molecule of O2 is highest and occurs where saturation is nearly 100%. This phenomenon is described as positive cooperativity.

questions.text: Routine spirometry cannot estimate
questions.solution: Residual volume cannot be measured by spirometry, lung capacities that include the residual volume also cannot be measured by spirometry (i.e.,FRC and TLC).

questions.text: Which of the following variants of hypoxia does not stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors
questions.solution:
• Peripheral chemoreceptors located in the carotid and aortic arteries sense changes in the Po2, pH, and Pco2 of the plasma.
  • The blood flow in each 2-mg carotid body is enormous about 2000 mL/100 g of tissue/min, and the O2 needs of the cells can be met largely by dissolved O2 alone.
  • In anemia the amount of dissolved O2 in the blood reaching the receptors is generally normal, even though the combined O2 in the blood is markedly decreased hence they do not stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in mountain climbers
questions.solution:
Bradycardia is not among the changes seen in mountain climbers.

Summary of adaptive responses to high altitude:

questions.solution:
• 1,25 DHCC : ↑Ca, ↑P
  • PTH : ↑Ca, ↓P
  • Calcitonin : ↓Ca, ↓P

questions.text: In stress which hormone is increased
questions.solution:
Vasopressin is the hormone on the above options which will be increased in stress.

 

 

Hormones increased in stress  Hormones decreased in stress  
CRF, ACTH and cortisol  GnRh, Gonadotropins 
Catecholamine  TSH and  T3,T4 
Prolactin(it may decrease) , Growth hormone  Insulin 
Vasopressin

questions.text: Secretion of all the hormones are decreased in section of pituitary stalk except
questions.solution:
The normal prolactin secretion is tonically inhibited by the hypothalamus, and the section of pituitary stalk leads to an increase in circulating prolactin.

NOTE- The effect of hypothalamic prolactin inhibiting hormone, dopamine, is normally greater than the effects of various hypothalamic peptides with prolactin-releasing activity.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an effect of T3 hormone:
questions.solution:
T3 causes increased protein breakdown and not decreased protein breakdown.

Physiologic effects of thyroid hormone

Target tissue Effect Mechanism
Heart Chronotropic and inotropic

Increased number of β-adrenergic receptors

Enhanced responses to circulating catecholamines

Increased proportion of α-myosin heavy chain (with higher ATPase activity)
Adipose tissue Catabolic Stimulated lipolysis
Muscle Catabolic Increased protein breakdown
Bone Developmental Promote normal growth and skeletal development
Nervous system Developmental Promote normal brain development
Gut Metabolic Increased rate of carbohydrate absorption
Lipoprotein Metabolic Formation of LDL receptors
Others Calorigenic Stimulated oxygen consumption by metabolically active tissues (exceptions: testes,uterus, lymph nodes, spleen, anterior pituitary)Increased metabolic rate

questions.text: Insulin is essential for glucose entry in:
questions.solution:
Insulin is essential for glucose entry in adipose tissue.

Adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, and cardiac muscle have GLUT-4 transporters that are insulin-dependent.

Glucose transporters

  Function Major sites of expression
Secondary active transport (Na + -glucose cotransport)  
SGLT 1 Absorption of glucose Small intestine, renal tubules
SGLT 2 Absorption of glucose Renal tubules
Facilitated diffusion  
GLUT 1 Basal glucose uptake Placenta, blood-brain barrier, brain, red cells, kidneys, colon, many other organs
GLUT 2 β-cell glucose sensor; transport out of intestinal and renal epithelial cells β cells of islets, liver, epithelial cells of small intestine, kidneys
GLUT 3 Basal glucose uptake Brain, placenta, kidneys
GLUT 4 Insulin-stimulated glucose uptake Skeletal and cardiac muscle, adipose tissue, other tissues
GLUT 5 Fructose transport Jejunum, sperm
GLUT 6 Unknown Brain, spleen, and leukocytes
GLUT 7 Glucose 6-phosphate transporter in the endoplasmic reticulum Liver

questions.text: Site of RBC formation in a 25 yrs old healthy male is ______.
questions.solution:
Hematopoiesis beyond 20 years of age occurs mainly in flat bones.

The marrow of the long bones, except for the proximal portions of the humeri and tibiae, becomes quite fatty and produces no more red blood cells after about age 20 years.

Beyond this age, most red cells continue to be produced in the marrow of the membranous bones, such as the vertebrae, sternum, ribs, and ilia. Even in these bones, the marrow becomes less productive as age increases.

Site of hematopoiesis:

  • Early embryonic life - Yolk sac
  • Middle trimester of gestation (>3 months of Intrauterine life) - Liver (main), spleen, lymph nodes
  • Last month of gestation/at birth - Bone marrow
  • Till 20 years of age - Axial skeleton and long bones
  • >20years - Flat bones

questions.text: The filtration of proteins by kidneys is restricted by
questions.solution:
Proteins like albumin are restricted from filtration because of its negative charge and the electrostatic repulsion exerted by negative charges of the glomerular capillary wall sialoproteins (proteoglycans)

Factors Affecting Renal Permeability (Filterability)

Two important factors that affect the permeability are molecular size and the charge of the substance

  • Molecular size
    • For neutral substances with a molecular diameter 4 to 8 nm filtration is inversely proportional to molecular diameter
  • Charge of the substance
    • The renal filtration membrane is composed of negatively charged sialoproteins (proteoglycans). As a result the negatively charged (anionic) proteins are less filtered and cationic substances are more readily filtered than neutral substances.
    • In glomerular disease, the anionic charges on the barrier may be removed, resulting in proteinuria.

questions.text: Effect of efferent arteriole constriction on GFR is:
questions.solution:
• At moderate levels of constriction, there is a slight increase in GFR, but with severe constriction, there is a decrease in GFR.
  • Constriction of the efferent arterioles increases the resistance to outflow from the glomerular capillaries. This mechanism raises glomerular hydrostatic pressure, and as long as the increase in efferent resistance does not reduce renal blood flow too much, GFR increases slightly.
  • However, because efferent arteriolar constriction also reduces renal blood flow, the plasma protein concentration increases and hence glomerular colloid osmotic pressure increases (Donnan effect). Therefore, if constriction of efferent arterioles is severe (more than about a threefold increase in efferent arteriolar resistance), the rise in colloid osmotic pressure exceeds the increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure caused by efferent arteriolar constriction. When this situation occurs, the net force for filtration actually decreases, causing a reduction in GFR.

questions.text: Hyperosmolarity of the renal medulla is due to increased
questions.solution:
• Corticomedullary osmotic gradient is primarily due to  NaCl and urea.
    • It is established by countercurrent multiplication and urea recycling.
    • It is maintained by countercurrent exchange in the vasa recta.
  • Countercurrent multiplication in the loop of Henle
    • It depends on NaCl reabsorption in the thick ascending limb and countercurrent flow in the descending and ascending limbs of the loop of Henle
  • Urea recycling from the inner medullary collecting ducts into the medullary interstitial fluid
  • Vasa recta are the capillaries that supply the loop of Henle. They maintain the corticomedullary gradient by serving as osmotic exchangers. Vasa recta blood equilibrates osmotically with the interstitial fluid of the medulla and papilla.

questions.text: Angiotensin II causes all of the following except
questions.solution:
Actions of Angiotensin II

Actions of Angiotensin II
  • Produces powerful arteriolar constriction and a rise in SBP and DBP
  • Acts directly on the adrenal cortex to increase aldosterone secretion
  • Facilitates the release of Norepinephrine by a direct action on postganglionic sympathetic neurons
  • Contraction of mesangial cells with a resultant decrease in GFR
  • Direct effect on renal tubules to increase Na+ reabsorption
  • Acts on brain to decrease sensitivity of baroreceptor reflex, potentiating the pressor effect of AT II
  • Acts on brain to increase water intake and increase secretion of ADH and ACTH

questions.text: Most potent stimulus for secretin is
questions.solution:
Most potent stimulus for secretin is acid. Fats are of secondary importance.

Releasers of gastrointestinal hormones

  • S → Primary physiologic stimulus for release
  • S- → Stimulus of secondary importance
  • I → Inhibits release physiologically
Releaser Gastrin CCK Secretin GIP Motilin
Protein S S 0 S 0
Fat 0 S S- S S-
Carbohydrate 0 0 0 S 0
Acid I S- S 0 S-
Distension S 0 0 0 0
Nerve S 0 0 0 S

questions.text: Migrating motor complex

choices.text: Begins in lower part of intestine
Occurs at a rate of 5cm/min in stomach

questions.solution:
Migrating motor complex are the modified pattern of electrical and motor activity in gastrointestinal smooth muscle that occur during fasting between periods of digestion.

  • These cycles (MMC) migrate from stomach to the distal ileum.
  • They are initiated by motilin.
  • The contractions migrate aborally at a rate of about 5cm/min, and also occur at intervals of approximately 100 minutes.
  • Gastric secretion, bile flow, and pancreatic secretion increase during each MMC. They likely serve to clear the stomach and small intestine of luminal contents in preparation for the next meal.
  • Upon ingestion of a meal secretion of motilin is suppressed and the MMC is abolished.

questions.text: Leptin level in obesity are:
questions.solution:
• Leptin is an appetite supressing hormone secreted by fat cells. Thus, as fat stores increase and more leptin is released, food intake is inhibited and energy expenditure is increased.
  • Most obese people have high circulating level of leptin but the paradox is that the appetite suppressing effect is not seen in them.
    • Leptin resistance in obese persons may be due to its failure to cross the blood-brain barrier and reach the hypothalamus.
    • A recent study has indicated that triglycerides, which are elevated in obesity, inhibit the transport of leptin across the blood-brain barrier.

questions.text: EDRF Induced vasodilatation is mediated by
questions.solution:
• EDRF Induced vasodilatation is mediated by Increased intracellular cGMP.
  • Endothelial cells produce endothelial derived relaxing factor (EDRF) , a substance that is now known to be Nitric oxide (NO).
  • NO and ANP hormone act via increasing intracellular cGMP.

questions.text: Acidophils secrete
questions.solution:
Acidophils secrete:

  • Lactotroph (10 – 30 %)
  • Somatotroph (50%)

Basophils secrete:

  • Gonadotroph (20%)
  • Corticotroph (10%)
  • Thyrotrope (5%)

questions.text: Mineralocorticoid receptors are present in all of the following marked sites except
questions.solution:
The marked site B indicates Liver in which mineralocorticoid receptors are absent.

Mineralocorticoid receptors are present in:

  • Kidney
  • Colon
  • Salivary gland
  • Sweat gland
  • Hippocampus of brain

questions.text: Blood testis barrier is formed by
questions.solution: Cytoplasmic processes from Sertoli cells along with tight junctions forms blood testis barrier.

questions.text: A gastric muscle was taken and electrical and mechanical recording was done. All of the following statements are true about the recording except?

choices.text: Tension developed proportionally to the frequency of spike potential
Tension developed directly proportionally to the amplitude of spike potentials

questions.solution:
Tension depends on the frequency of spike potentials.

From the x axis , the frequency is 1 per 10 sec or 6 per min.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of gut flora

choices.text: Synthesis of short chain fatty acids

questions.solution:
Colonic bacteria cause increased proliferation and differentiation of epithelial cells.

Other functions are:

  • Fermentation of non-digestible dietary residue and endogenous mucus.
  • Production of Short chain fatty acids and Vitamin K.
  • Absorption of ions.
  • Development and homeostasis of immune system.
  • Protection against pathogens

questions.text: Pseudounipolar cells are
questions.solution:
• Pseudounipolar cells are present in dorsal root ganglion.
  • Motor neuron, cerebellar purkinje cells and pyramidal cells of hippocampus are examples of multipolar neurons.

Types of neurons:

  • Unipolar neuron:
    • Single process with different segments serving as receptive and releasing terminals.
    • Present only in invertebrates
  • Bipolar neuron:
    • Has one axon (releasing terminal) and one dendrite (receptive terminal)
    • Example – Bipolar cells of retina
  • Pseudounipolar neuron:
    • Subtype of bipolar neuron
    • Single process divides into 2 axons – one supplying skin or muscle and another goes to spinal cord.
  • Multipolar neuron:
    • Has one axon and several dendrites.
    • Examples - motor neurons, hippocampal pyramidal cells with dendrites in the apex and base, and cerebellar Purkinje cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true

choices.text: K+ is the main determinant of RMP
RMP of neuron is close to Isoelectric potential of K+
RMP of neuron is equal to Isoelectric potential of Cl-

questions.solution:
The intracellular and extracellular K+ concentrations are the prime determinants of the resting membrane potential.

RMP of neuron is -70 mV.

It is close to isoelectric potential of K+ and equal to isoelectric potential of Cl-.

questions.text: Decrease in extracellular calcium concentration
questions.solution:
A decrease in extracellular Ca2+ concentration increases the excitability of nerve and muscle cells by decreasing the amount of depolarization necessary to initiate the changes in the Na+ and K+ conductance that produce the action potential.

Conversely, an increase in extracellular Ca2+ concentration can stabilize the membrane by decreasing excitability.
